column2: Average Class Size and Class Size Distribution (Elementary)\r2016-172016-172016-172016-172017-182017-182017-182017-182018-192018-192018-192018-19\rAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# of\rGrade\rClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*\rLevel\rSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSize\r1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+\rK\r202422141924\r\r1\r2342442122\r\r2\r2113254254\r\r3\r224224254\r\r4\r22233032513\r\r5\r2942313313\r\r6\r262326232223\r\rOther**\r82\r*Numbe r of classes indicates how many classes fall into each size category (a range of total students per class).\r** “Other” category is for multi-grade level classes.\r\r\rProfessional Development provided for Teachers\r\rMeasure2017-182018-192019-20\rNumber of school days dedicated to Staff Development and Continuous Improvement222\r\rThis section provides information on the annual number of school days dedicated to staff development for the most recent three-year period.\rThe Turlock Unified School District Local Control Accountability Plan prioritized district-wide professional development opportunities for TK-12 to include\rsubject matter
column7: PLC’s and leadership. Multiple measures including CAASPP\rresults
column10: and data from site educational rounds were utilized to prioritize needs. Additionally
column11: \rTUSD’s initiatives and staff input continue to drive the professional development offerings.\rStaff is provided with weekly embedded collaboration time in addition to opportunities for extended collaboration at site determined periods throughout\rthe school year.  The collaboration time allows teachers to apply new learning and make strategic decisions regarding the use of curriculum and\rassessments.\r\rYear one and year two teachers are enrolled in TUSD’s Induction Program which is in the second year of implementation. The Induction Program activities\rare based on the California Standards for the Teaching Profession which outlines the numerous interconnected skills that comprise the professional\rpractices of teaching. New administrators are supported through their participation in the Stanislaus County Office of Education Administrator Induction\rProgram.\r\rProfessional development and support has been provided in the following areas: Professional Learning Communities; Math Instruction; ELA/ELD\rInstruction; Special Education; Instructional Best Practices; Guided Language Acquisition and Design (GLAD); Advanced Placement;  Technology; Digital\rCitizenship
column12: Small Group Instruction; and Next Generation Science Standards. Professional development opportunities occur during a combination of the\rregular school day
column14: and during the summer. TUSD has a network of nineteen content specialist instructional coaches that are utilized to\rsupport staff in classroom implementation as a follow up to all professional development events.\rThere are several formal Special Education administrative and teacher trainings scheduled each year that include the following topics: Service delivery\rfor special education students with various handicapping conditions

The collaboration time allows teachers to apply new learning and make strategic decisions regarding the use of curriculum and\rassessments.\r\rYear one and year two teachers are enrolled in TUSD’s Induction Program which is in the second year of implementation.
